For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.

Given a ring $R$ and a multiplicative system $S \subset R$, the localization $S^{-1}R$ (or $R_S$) is the ring of fractions $ rac{a}{s}$ where $a \in R$ and $s \in S$, under an equivalence relation defined by $ rac{a}{s} =  rac{a'}{s'}$ if there exists some $s'' \in S$ such that $as's'' = a'ss''$.

A polynomial $f \in R[X]$ with coefficients in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called primitive if the greatest common divisor of all its coefficients is 1, or equivalently, if $
u_p(f) = 0$ for all prime elements $p \in R$.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
The residue class module M/N of an A-module M by a submodule N is defined analogously to the quotient space in vector spaces, where M/N consists of the cosets of N in M.
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Submodule (ID: 8) is a specialization of an A-module (ID: 6) because it is defined as a subset of an A-module that is closed under the operations of the A-module, inheriting all properties and operations of an A-module.

A Residue class module (ID: 9) is a specialization of an A-module (ID: 6) because it is formed by taking the quotient of an A-module by one of its submodules, thus inheriting the structure and operations of an A-module.
A System of generators (ID: 10) is a specialization of an A-module (ID: 6) because it describes a specific way of generating an A-module using a set of elements from the A-module.

A Finitely generated module (ID: 11) is a specialization of an A-module (ID: 6) because it is an A-module that can be generated by a finite number of elements, thus inheriting all properties of an A-module.

A Free system of generators (basis) (ID: 12) is a specialization of an A-module (ID: 6) because it describes a specific type of system of generators that is linearly independent, inheriting the structure and operations of an A-module.
